justification: The authors write that they "applied a longitudinal design in a large cohort of adolescents and young adults to study peer influence on a well characterised task measuring delay discounting—a key measure of temporal impulsivity." This links impulsivity with the delay-discounting measure.

measured_by: Change in discount rate after observing peer
Social shift score in the Social Delay Discounting Task
justification: "Here, we defined susceptibility to social influence as the degree of change in one's own discount rate towards the preference of a social partner, following exposure to the preferences of a social partner."

measured_by: Taste-uncertainty parameter of Bayesian computational model
justification: The paper states that "we used a previously validated formal computational model to estimate an individual 'taste uncertainty' parameter," indicating that this model-derived parameter operationalises the construct.
Under Psychometric Measures the authors note: "We used the Cambridge Friendship Questionnaire (CFQ) to assess the perceived quality of peer relations."
The Methods section reports analysing "externalising behaviours ... assessed using the behaviours checklist questionnaire."
The same passage states that "alcohol consumption [was] assessed using the behaviours checklist questionnaire."
